awd_titl_txt: CRISP 2.0 Type 2: Collaborative Research: Organizing Decentralized Resilience in Critical Interdependent-infrastructure Systems and Processes (ORDER-CRISP)
awd_abstract_narration:
This Critical Resilient Interdependent Infrastructure Systems and Processes (CRISP) project develops an integrated resilience modeling framework for mitigating vulnerabilities in critical interdependent infrastructure systems. The framework evaluates the coupled nature of vulnerabilities across physical and social systems in Miami and Houston. By focusing on the effects of recent hurricanes on the interdependent-infrastructures in energy, water, transportation and telecommunication, and the human-infrastructures interactions, the project explores options for resilience. The system vulnerabilities are quantified with regional inoperability based economic-interdependency models. The project will also develop a mobile phone app for information sharing with the public.  Thus, this scientific research contribution supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare with benefits that will optimize investments in the nation's critical infrastructures.  

The project integrates risk-based models, agent-based simulations, dynamic models of social vulnerability, and models of economic impacts of inoperability. The novelty lies in integrating the interdisciplinary research components: (i) incorporating wind and flood inundation risk into the utility and service disruption models to analyze and determine the extent of interdependent infrastructure failures in energy, water, transportation, and telecommunication sectors; (ii) constructing socio-infrastructural systems of vulnerability and analyzing evacuation/relocation behavior to assess the need for emergent critical infrastructure services; (iii) micro simulation for analyzing coping behavior and facilitating decentralized resilience through information sharing and critical resource pooling; (iv) a macro (city level) inoperability based resilience model to integrate household and social responses with disrupted interdependent infrastructure systems; and (v) developing an app to facilitate and scale up participatory resilience through crowd-sourcing which will be usable in other disaster settings. The project will engage, mentor, and offer an innovative active learning environment for K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students by giving priority to the disadvantaged and underrepresented communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In ORDER-CRISP (CRISP 2.0 Type 2: Collaborative Research: Organizing Decentralized Resilience in Critical Interdependent-infrastructure Systems and Processes, ORDER-CRISP), we have investigated the effects of recent hurricanes on the interdependent-infrastructures (e.g., energy, water, transportation, and telecommunication) and the human-infrastructures interactions. We have analyzed household and community level adaptation and coping behaviors with disruptive interdependent-infrastructure systems and connect these behaviors with regional inoperability based economic-interdependence models. We have also developed a platform to gather and disseminate information to organize decentralized resilience (by information sharing and resource pooling) as a cascade proofing mechanism. Alongside, with determining risk exposures to disruptive interdependent systems and subsequent recovery processes, we have developed complementary pathways for enhancing coastal resilience.

 

In this six-year-long project, we have collected and analyzed spatially explicit granular data of utility services disruptions and uncovered nuanced layers of risk exposures to interdependent infrastructure systems and emergent recovery processes for enhancing resilience in vulnerable communities. Our analytical tools and techniques pushed the frontiers of interdisciplinary approaches for analyzing social-environmental-technological hazards and disruptions in complex systems in major coastal communities (which are published in 35 peer-reviewed journal articles and 36 conference presentations). A group of students and postdocs at the Florida International University (3 female PhD students and 5 male PhD students; 2 female master’s students; 1 female undergraduate student and 1 male undergraduate student; 1 female postdoc and 2 male postdocs) has been mentored by utilizing data, methods and analytical frameworks developed through this project. The published research contributions from this team effort can be categorized into four broad topics: (1) Hurricane Impact, Damage & Infrastructure Resilience, (2) Evacuation Behavior & Decision‐Making, (3) Coastal Vulnerability, Sea‑Level Rise & Flood Adaptation, and (4) Land Subsidence, Migration, other related issues. We have also developed an extensive network of stakeholders to gain insights into the effects of extreme weather events on interdependent infrastructures and these interactions with stakeholders provided ground-truthing evidence to validate our analyses and outputs. Utilizing resources from this project we have extended institutional capacity to collect spatially referenced large household survey data from hurricane impacted areas to track damage, disruption and the dynamics of recovery processes at a granular level. 

 

The overall project is a multi-university collaboration and in collaboration with the University of Virginia, we have developed a web app for residents living in vulnerable areas to help each other by sharing information and resources in a natural disaster situation. While this web app requires further testing, it is functional and more than a prototype. When it is ready to be deployed in natural disasters, we expect that affected communities and concerned public, private and civic organizations will be able to uncover how people prepare, cope and respond under diverse constraints and challenges in a disaster. We hope that with more resources and additional features, this platform will be useful for improving disaster management practices and societal well-being during crises. Through this research and broader impact activities, we have not only made intellectual contributions but also made our communities aware of the nuanced processes of risk exposures caused by extreme weather events and the benefit of proactive measures to expedite recovery and promote resilience.
